content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @markwylde No, it doesn't have to be this way, but it is (almost) always this way. When a programming language makes it too easy to manage dependencies, you inevitably get microdependencies. It doesn't help that many people learn JavaScript or Python as their first language.

@mckinley@twtxt.net Thankfully less so in Go, because of the culture around the language, but I used to feel this way about Python too once upon a time, I feel like languages and ecosystems get ‚Äúpopulated‚Äù with ideas from every other language/ecosystem over time and eventually reach a state of ‚Äúchaos‚Äù? ü§î As an example, Go now supports generics as of Go 1.19, something I‚Äôm not really all that thrilled with really as it adds unnecessary complexity to the language IMO that isn‚Äôt really needed.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @markwylde No, it doesn't have to be this way, but it is (almost) always this way. When a programming language makes it too easy to manage dependencies, you inevitably get microdependencies. It doesn't help that many people learn JavaScript or Python as their first language.

@mckinley@twtxt.net Is right here, as much as I‚Äôm strongly opinionated on the subject, there is no ‚Äúhard‚Äù and ‚Äúfast‚Äù (right or wrong) rule here. There are only ‚Äúrules of thumb‚Äù, ‚Äúguidelines‚Äù and ‚Äúexperience‚Äù.

And as @mckinley@twtxt.net nicely points out, the real problem is likely the exponential effect of dependencies. Fortunately or unfortunately (depending on how you look at it) libraries can also have dependencies (and good language really will support this), but the thing we often refer to as ‚Äúdependency hell‚Äù comes from this ‚Äúexponential dependency tree‚Äù that we inevitably see in ecosystems like NodeJS / NPM (are there other examples? I feel like I pick on NodeJS / NPM too much ü§£)

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @markwylde No, it doesn't have to be this way, but it is (almost) always this way. When a programming language makes it too easy to manage dependencies, you inevitably get microdependencies. It doesn't help that many people learn JavaScript or Python as their first language.

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs the tools fault per se ü§ó It‚Äôs a educational problem I think. Not everything has to be a library / dependency:

Copying and Pasting code is ‚Äúokay‚Äù üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª The problem isn't with NodeJS or NPM, it's the developers that are so willing to use horrible frameworks/libraries/tooling that is just simply not needed. NodeJS gives you so much out of the box, and NPM is simply a place to store your packages. With Deno, you won't even need a package manager as it takes a step closer to go modules approach.

Your primary arguments is basisally ‚Äúframeworks‚Äù and I completely agree! üíØ I like Go a lot because the culture and ecosystem tends to encourage libraries over frameworks and standard library over external dependencies üëå

One thing we‚Äôve talked about in the past is this ridiculous culture in the NPM (note I‚Äôm deliberately not mentioning JavaScript or NodeJS here) of packaging the tiniest / stupidest things as a ‚Äúlibrary‚Äù

This is how (I think) you end up with 10k dependencies ü§£

The problem isn't with NodeJS or NPM, it's the developers that are so willing to use horrible frameworks/libraries/tooling that is just simply not needed. NodeJS gives you so much out of the box, and NPM is simply a place to store your packages. With Deno, you won't even need a package manager as it takes a step closer to go modules approach.

Your primary arguments is basisally ‚Äúframeworks‚Äù and I completely agree! üíØ I like Go a lot because the culture and ecosystem tends to encourage libraries over frameworks and standard library over external dependencies üëå
One thing we‚Äôve talked about in the past is this ridiculous culture in the NPM (note I‚Äôm deliberately not mentioning JavaScript or NodeJS here) of packaging the tiniest / stupidest things as a ‚Äúlibrary‚Äù
This is how (I think) you end up with 10k dependencies ü§£

Key @Kevin@oh.mg I was trying to improve the way external feeds are cached and handled as well as their avatars. Removing duplicates, reducing memory footprint, etc. I noticed your feed is served over 3 different protocols https, gopher and gemini. I also noticed you moved your feed‚Äôs primary URL (the one we consider for Twt Hashes) from https://om.gay/text/twtxt.txt to https://txt.om.gay/twtxt.txt

However when I try to access the these feeds I see a different (first) # url = value at the top:

  • https://gopher.mills.io/oh.mg/0/twtxt.txt
  • https://om.gay/text/twtxt.txt

The first one shows:

# url = https://txt.om.gay/twtxt.txt

Whilst the 2nd one shows:

# url = https://om.gay/text/twtxt.txt

This makes clients confused üòÖ

I also noticed you moved your feed‚Äôs primary URL (the one we consider for Twt Hashes) from https://om.gay/text/twtxt.txt to https://txt.om.gay/twtxt.txt

https://gopher.mills.io/oh.mg/0/twtxt.txt
